person.note: So according to Epiphanius, in the Syriac script (Wendland, Aristeae, 143), see Introduction 2.8.3.

On Arist see Introduction 6.2.1 and Cohen, JSJ 15 (1984) 58, who claims this is a derivation of the biblical name אביה. She concedes however, that the name has undergone a degree of Hellenization. The name is recorded elsewhere in Egyptian antiquity, even among Jews (CPJ 1, 200). See also above, n. 1.
For dating of Arist see Introduction 7.1.1.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
This is the declension recorded in the document.
On persons designated “high priest” in the sources see Introduction 3.2.5.

See Introduction 6.2. Zosimos tells us that Asenas, a high priest from Jerusalem, placed a version of the Greek Bible in the Serapeum at the time of the Ptolemies. Zosimos was an alchemist who lived in Egypt in the first centuries (?) of the Christian era. His knowledge of Jewish history is very hazy, particularly when referring to events that took place three centuries earlier than his own. Also, we do not know what his sources of information were and his syncretistic attitude puts into question all historical information about Jews.
Zosimos dates him to the time of the Ptolemies. This is the date of their demise.
On dating of the Masada documents see Introduction 7.8.
This declension is recorded in the document.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.
On second names see Introduction 6.1.3. This is a nickname, because it was given jointly to two brothers.
On dating according to NT see Introduction 7.3.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
This declension is recorded in the document. For the interchange of ε and ι, see Introduction 2.3.2.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
I assume this is the same name. The editor offered no emended reading.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.
See Introduction 6.1.1.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

person.bibl: Acta Pilati A: 9 (Tischendorf,EA245); Arabic Infancy Gospel (Sike,Evangelium Infantiae, 67).
person.note: So in the Arabic infancy Gospel (=Titus), see Introduction 2.8.5.
This story names the nameless Gospels hero (e.g. Mark 15:27). On this phenomenon see Introduction 1.1.2.2. In this case it is an unnamed male who is named.
All figures appearing in apocryphal Christian documents are considered fictitious, see Introduction 6.2.2.
This book all takes place on the year of Jesus’ execution.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.
On the date of the sect founders in Eusebius, see Introduction 7.4.2.
The declension is recorded in the document.
See Introduction 6.1.1.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.
These are the years of King Yannai’s reign according to Josephus.

person.bibl: Acta Pilati A: 9 (Tischendorf,EA245); Arabic Infancy Gospel (Sike,Evangelium Infantiae, 67).
person.note: So in the Arabic Infancy Gospel (=Dumachus), see Introduction 2.8.5.
This story names the nameless Gospels hero (e.g. Mark 15:27). On this phenomenon see Introduction 1.1.2.2. In this case it is an unnamed male who is named.
All figures appearing in apocryphal Christian documents are considered fictitious, see Introduction 6.2.2.
This book all takes place on the year of Jesus’ execution.
Epiphanius believed this was a real name, but it means “pauper” in Hebrew (אביון) and it is likely that the name of the sect was chosen from this word, and not based on the name of the founder.
He is described by Epiphanius as a contemporary of Cerinthus (G/M), see under him.
All figures appearing in apocryphal Christian documents are considered fictitious, see Introduction 6.2.2.
This book all takes place on the year of Jesus’ execution.
On second names see Introduction 6.1.3. This is certainly a second name and not a father’s name, because this person’s father was called Simon (no. 30).
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
See Introduction 6.1.1.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.
So in Josephus.
On second names see Introduction 6.1.3. On the second names of the Hasmonean brothers, see Hachlili, EI17 (1984) 196.
On dating in 1 Macc, seeIntroduction 7.1.2.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.
This is the declension recorded in the document.

So according to Epiphanius, in the Syriac script (Wendland, Aristeae, 143), see Introduction 2.8.3.
On Arist see Introduction 6.2.1 and Cohen, JSJ 15 (1984) 62. She claims the name in its present form is non-identifiable. It is not recorded elsewhere in Egyptian antiquity.
For dating of Arist see Introduction 7.1.1.
So in ms. versions. This has led to the suggestion that the name derives from the sectarian designation “Sicaruis” (e.g. Hengel Zealots, 47-8, n. 192).
So in the more Hellenized versions of Matt, e.g. 10:4, and John e.g. 6:71.
On second names see Introduction 6.1.3.
On dating according to NT see Introduction 7.3.
So in other mss.
So in BJ 4:271.
So in BJ 5:250.

On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

The identification between Cephas and Peter is made clear in John 1:42. However, for the suggestion that Cephas not be identified with Peter of the Synoptic Gospels see B. D. Ehrman, “Cephas and Peter,” JBL 109 (1990) 463-74.
On second names see Introduction 6.1.3. This name was obviously given to Simon as a second name (or nickname) see John 1:42.
On dating according to NT see Introduction 7.3.

On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
The declension is recorded in the document.

The document is bilingual. This is the suggested reading of the editor in Hebrew characters. The word is obviously a translation of this person’s name, also meaning “hunchback,” and see also under גביהה (Gabiha – S-H/M)

See above, n. 2. On second names see Introduction 6.1.3. This is certainly a second name and not a father’s name, because this person’s father was also called Mattathias (no. 13). This is certainly a second name and not a father’s name, because this person’s father was Yohanan (no. 94).
On the dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

The declension is recorded in the document. On such declensions see Introduction 2.3.5.1. It may indicate a place of origin, see above, n. 1. WGE, 759, mention the city of Λαγανία in Galatia. Alternatively, לגין/לגינא means “bottle, vessel” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 692).
This is either some sort of nickname, or, if it is the proselyte’s father’s name, than he is not a Jew, since his son converted to Judaism.
See Introduction 6.1.1.

person.note: This is the suggested reading of the editor.

This is an alternative reading of this name in the mss. On the ωθ suffix see Introduction 2.4.4.2. מרגלות means “the bottom part of a bedstead” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 836).
See Introduction 6.1.1.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

The form ברנבו is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 79). Perhaps this is also a compound name, although NT tends to join the two elements (son of + name) together, see Introduction 2.1.1.2.1, which rather puts such a suggestion in doubt. The form Ναβαῖος is recorded on a papyrus from Egypt (Forabaschi, Onomasticon, 202).
See Introduction 6.1.1.
On dating according to NT see Introduction 7.3.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

div.note: This is not a recorded Greek name. WGE, 3, mentions a town by the name of ̓Αβιήτα in south-eastern Europe (Rumania). The form אביתי is recorded on Aramaic documents from Egypt (TADAE 4, 7.57, 8.4, 8.9, 8.10, 9.15). אביתי and אבותי are found also in documents from Elephantine for women (TADAE 3, 3.28; 4, no. 18.16). All these are 3rd C BCE examples. It is also recorded in Greek in Egypt (Preisigke, NB, 2). The form אביתע is recorded among Idumeans (AOFCI, no. 34).
אתרוגא/אתרונגא is the name of a citrus fruit in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 134). Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 1, 331, 332; Reuveni, Lĕšonénu 2 (1930) 47.

In Egypt the name ̓Ανάβασις is recorded (Preisigke, NB. 29), as well as the form ̓Αναβοῦς (Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 32). It may derive from the Egyptian deity Anubis. See also ̓Ανάβους (WGE, 82). אנבא means “fruit” or “lice egg” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 80). Alternatively, DJD2, interpret this name as derived from the Semitic root ענב. They note that it is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 106) and associate it also with the Biblical town of this name (Josh 11:21). עינב is recorded in Idumea (AOFCI, 178).

This is the Greek rendering of the name of the famous Carthaginian general Hannibal, (WGE, 92). The comparative biblical name is חניאל (Num 34:23). Schalit (NB, 13, following Schlatter, HN, 121), suggests the name ̓Αντίπαςhere, but there are no textual traces for such a suggestion.

The form is not recorded as a Greek name either in WGE or in Preisigke, NB. The closest example is ̓Ασενεθ/̓Ασανηθ (Preisigke, NB, 60), perhaps an Egyptian name, and cf. the name of Joseph’s Egyptian wife – אסנת (̓Ασενεθ/̓Ασεννεθ/̓Ασσενεθ in LXX, H. & R. Suppl., 23-4), which is perhaps an Egyptian name.

This is not a recorded Greek name. WGE, 157, mentions the name ̓́Ασκαλος associated with the town of Ashkelon. The name, as such, is recorded in Egypt (Preisegke, NB, 61). Lidzbarski, Ephemeris 2, 7, views ̓Ασκαλᾶςas an abbreviation of a name with the theophoric element ̓Ασκληπιός. On such Greek names see Introduction 1.2.1.

Βακερος is not a recorded Greek name. In LXX the name בקי (Num 34:22) is transliterated Βακχείρ; Βακκείρ (H & R Suppl. 34). This may be the name intended. On the κχ transliteration see Introduction 2.1.2.4. DJD 2, 227, interpret it as deriving from the Hebrew בכר – young camal. Alternatively, בקר means “oxen, cattle” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 187). בקר is recorded as a name for Arabs, (Harding, ICPIANI, 113).

This is an unusual name. The only name that seems remotely close to it was בונור, recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 9). The text itself explains the name as “sons of thunder,” perhaps suggesting בני רעם. The Βοανη represents בני and the ργες רעם. For γ transliterating ע see Introduction 2.1.2.1.

This is not a recorded Greek name. WGE, 220, mentions a town by the name of Βορκέως north of Judaea. Perhaps this person is a native of the city. Schalit’s suggested this is the transliteration of the Semitic name בורקאי (NB, 29). ברקוס (=son of the Edomite God Kos) is mentioned among the names of the netinim (Ezra 2:53). Naveh, Mas I, 21, interpreted the name as meaning “the morning star,” and see also under ברוקא (Beroqa – S-H/M). ברק and ברקס are recorded as names for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 102). ברק is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 21). Alternatively, בורכא means “absurdity” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 150).

This is not a recorded Greek name. WGE, 236, mentions similar names associated with the town of Gaza. For the Greekγ transliterating the Hebrew ע, see Introduction 2.1.2.1. ע'זי is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 455). עזי is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 105). Alternatively, גזא means “treasure” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 228). גזא/גזי means “to cut, to go one’s way, to repay” in Aramaic (Jastrow, ibid. 229). גזא is recorded as a name for an amora (Kosowsky,Babylonico, 330). גזיאת and גזמן are recorded names for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem32, nos. 224-5). DJD2, suggest that the name derives from the Semitic root גזר.
גשתא means “tube, siphon” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 274). This is the closest etymology I could come up with. The name is obviously a literary invention.

Josephus transliterates the name of the Galilean city (גוש חלב) as Γίσχαλα (Schalit, NB, 35), but this orthography is just as likely to denote the name. The name seems to be declined. For this transliteration of ח see Introduction 2.1.2.8. I read λ for the editor’s δ. The letters are easily interchangeable in Greek. DJD 2, 223, suggest this explanation as well.
גירותא is the name of an unclean bird in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 242). גוריתא means a female lion-cub (Jastrow, Ibid. 227).

גדם means “stumped” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 235, and also Hachlili, EI 17 [1984] 197). DJD 2, 232, suggest this explanation as well. However, גודמא means “trunk” in Aramaic (Jastrow, ibid. 218, 235). The Nabatean name גדימו (Greek Γαδιμος, Γαδεμος, Γαδιμαθος) is recorded, (Negev, Qedem 32, nos. 216, 2122, 2558).
דוגי means “dripping fat” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 282). See also Inroduction 2.4.1.5. The name Διγίττιος is recorded on an Egyptian papyrus (Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 92).
I have found no plausible explanation or parallel for this name, or for its variant in the Arabic version.
אביון means “poor, distressed” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 5). אביון appears as a variant for the name אבון in PT (Kosovsky,Yerushalmi, 35).
Cf. the biblical name of the wife of Haman – זרש (Esth 5:10).

This is not a recorded Greek name. WGE, 475, mentions a mountain in Campania,̔́Ηφαιον. It may be associated with the mythic ̔́Ηφαιστος. For an explanation of the name derived from Aramaic, see Schalit, NB, ibid.

This is not a recorded Greek name. WGE, 480, mention Θαμαναῖοι as a Persian people. In LXX Θαμανά is used as a transliteration of the biblical תמנע (H & R Suppl. 70). The names תמין and תמן (as female names) are recorded in Aramaic from Egypt (TADAE 4, 18.13, 8.7). The forms Θαμῆνις, Θαμεῖνις and Θαμῖνις are recorded in Egyptian papyri (probably as female names – Preisigke, NB, 206; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 131). Note also the Hebrew תימן – Yemen or south.

Θάσος is the name of a Greek island (WGE, 482). The name Θασσα is recorded from Cyrene (LGPN 1, 210). Θασῖς (as a female name) is recorded on Egyptian Papyri (Preisigke, NB, 129; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 132). The root תסס means “buble, ferment” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1683).

The Ια cluster at the beginning of this name suggests a transliteration of the Hebrew י. The name, however, is unique. LXX has ̓Ιαζειζ for יזיז (1 Chr 27:31), who is an Arab (H & R Suppl. 74). DJD 2, 228, suggested a Nabatean name. The Nabatean Ιζιδ and Ειζηδ are recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, nos. 2567, 2583). ̓Ιεζῖδ is recorded in Egypt (Preisigke, NB, 146, and 509, for the claim that it is Arabic). The name is used in Arabic to this day. יזד is recorded as a name for Arabs in antiquity(Harding, ICPIANI, 669). Alternatively, Justi, INB, 146, explains the “Yazd”/Ιαζειδ element as theophoric-Iranian.

This is a Greek transliteration of a Semitic name beginning with the letter י. The transliteration of ירקון, in LXX is ̓Ιερακών (H & R Suppl. 80). ירק means “green, pale” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 597). The name ירק is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 91-2). Alternatively, the form ̔Ιρακλείδυς, representing the Greek ̔Ηρεκλείδης, is recorded on an Egyptian papyrus (Preisigke, NB, 152).
In LXX this is a corrupt form of the name “Israel” in Amos 5:4 (H &R Suppl. 87).

The name is traditionally interpreted as including the Hebrew element איש and perhaps indicating a place of origin – קריות, e.g. in the translation of NT by F. Delitzch into Hebrew (איש קריות). קרייתא means “town, village” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1420). The non-declined form of this name suggests a Semitic name with ות suffix, see also Introduction 2.4.4.2.

קטלא means “killing” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1349). In rabbinic literature, another person, like this one, dating from the end of the Second Temple period and a member of one of the freedom groups of the time – אלעזר בן דינאי – is called son of the murderer (בן הרצחן – mSot. 9:9, and see under him App/M). In PT it is clearly stated בן הרוצחן ברא קטולה (ySot 9:8, 24a). For the interchange of θ, and τ see Introduction 2.1.2.3. Indeed in BJ 6:148 the name is recorded as ̓Ακατελᾶ (Schalit, NB, 69; Lieberman Greek, 181, n. 188; and also Schalit, Annual of the Swedish Theological Institute4 [1965] 170). Alternatively, כתלא means “wall” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 627). Καθῦλις is recorded as a name on a papyrus from Egypt (Preisigke, NB, 157). Further on this name see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 338.

כנדא means “a gown” and is borrowed from Persian (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 648). This person is also of Persian origins, but Justi, INB, records no such name. כנדא also means “pitcher, pot” in Aramaic (Jstrow, ibid.). A certain Κενδεβαῖος is mentioned in 1 Macc 15:38 as ἐπιστράτηγος of Trypho, a Seleucid pretender to the throne. He is, of course, not Jewish, and the origin of the name, whether it is the same as this one or not, is unclear. See also Introduction 2.4.1.5. For the name Κένδεος see WGE, 645. Κανδαῖος and Κενδέας are recorded in Egyptian papyri (Preisigke, NB, 164; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 163). Alternatively, the Nabatean קנדא is recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1034).

Many names with the element Κηφ are recorded in Greek (WGE, 655-6). The form Κεφᾶς is recorded on Egyptian papyri (Preisigke, NB, 173; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 164). It is, however, true that John 1:42 identifies the name as the Aramaic word for “rock” and therefore probably כיפה (Greek Πέτρος – Jastrow, DTTBYML, 635). The Aramaic name כפא is recorded from Elephantine (TADAE 2, 3:9). The name כפי is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 502). However, the etymology of John may be late, and see also below n. 2.

קולסיתא/קלוסיתא means “turban, head dress” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1329, 1373). The non-declined form of this name suggests a Semitic name with ות suffix, see Introduction 2.4.4.2. In Egypt the form Κλουσι[…] is recorded (Preisigke, NB, 177). Derenbourg, Essai, 281, n. 1, suggests identifying him with בן (ציצת) הכסת.

Josephus explains this name as emanating from that of the Idumean deity Kos. Other such names are recorded from the biblical period (CWSSSnos. 842, 1048-9, 1050-1, 1055-7). One of these names is קוסגבר King of Edom. When Simhoni translated Josephus into Hebrew, he used קוסגבר for Κοστόβαρος. More names of this sort are recorded for Idumeans (AOFCI, 100).

קורתא means “town, city” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1344, 1428). WGE, 745, mention the city of Κυρθάνιον on the shores of the Sea of Marmara. Κυραθοῦς is recorded as a name in Egypt (Preisigke, NB, 188). Alternatively, the root כרת means “cut, separate, excommunicate” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 674). כרת is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 498).

Κυρτός in Greek means “hunchback.” Thus, the name is obviously a Greek nickname. Although the form may also be recorded as a Greek name (WGE, 748), this is unlikely. WGE too records this asa nickname for a certain Joannes.
WGE, 759, mention the city of Λαγανία in Galatia. Alternatively, לגין/לגינא means “bottle, vessel” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 692).

למך is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 520). The biblical למך (e.g. Gen 4:18), however, is transliterated into Greek by LXX as Λάμεχ (H & R Suppl. 100) and by Josephus as Λάμεχος (e.g. AJ 1:63).

מגיס/מגס means “tray” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 726). The Nabatean מגס is recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 612). However, this name may be pronounced with a ש because of Josephus’ tendency to transliterate this letter with a double σ, see Introduction 2.1.2.6. Alternatively, WGE, 834, mentions the Greek name Μάγας. The name Μαγασενος is recorded in Cyrene (LGPN1, 295). Also, Justi, INB, 56, explains the Greek Μεγα/Μαγα as being authentically interchangeable with the Iranian “Baga”, and see under Bagadates (P/M).

מקבא means “mallet” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 829), and so the nickname of Judas Maccabee has been traditionally understood. Alternatively, מכב is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 561).

The suffix of this name leaves no doubt that it is the Hebrew theophoric אל. The name may be a variant of עמנואל because this is the way this name was later excerpted in many languages, in light of its influence in Christianity (Isa 7:14), and see already WGE, 855 (Μανουήλ). Alternatively, in LXX the form Μαναήλ is used for the biblical נחליאל (Num 21:19 – H & R Suppl. 106); מנאל is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 567).
מנון means “manager, executor” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 798). Μάνων is recorded as a name in Egypt (Preisigke, NB, 205).

מרגלא means “jewel” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 836). Schalit, NB, 82, explains this name so. Alternatively, WGE, 859, mentions the city of Μαργάλα in Elis, Greece. Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 345.

The root נבי/נבא means “burst forth, prophesy” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 868). נבי is recorded as a name on First Temple Hebrew seals, (CWSSSnos. 379, 530); for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 580); in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 98).

נאלא means “lamenting” or “fatigue” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 866). נאלת is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 578). Alternatively, the name may derive from the name of the river Nile (Νειλαῖος in Greek – WGE, 984). In Egyptian papyri the forms Νειλᾶς, Νειλεύς, Νεῖλος and Νειλοῦς are recorded, (Preisigke, NB, 227; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 203). The Nabatean ניל is recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 729).
פזמא means “leaping, haste” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1150). See also Introduction 2.4.1.5. For another explanation see DJD 2, 221.
This name is not recorded anywhere. For the formΣαυγένηςseeLGPNIIIb, 375.

This is probably a Semitic name with the component שר in it, perhaps שרמעלה. In LXX the form Σαράσαρ is used to transliterate שראצר (H & R Suppl. 138). The name Σαράμμων is recorded in Egyptian papyri (Preisigke, 363; NB, Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 280). It is probably another such name (perhaps שרהמון). Alternatively, Justi, INB, 288, records the Persian name Σαράμης.

There are many possibilities to explain this name. The biblical ישעי is transliterated in LXX as Σεεί (H & R Suppl. 140). Alternatively, שאי is recorded as a name for Arabs, (Harding, ICPIANI, 337). Σέεινε, Σέει and Σεεῖς are recorded on Egyptian papyri (Preisigke, NB, 367; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 284). Also, סאה means “measure of volume” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 947). Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 345.
The name is not Greek, but apparently Ithurian, and was the name of an Ithurian king (WGE, 1421). שים and שימן are recorded as names for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 364).

טפי/טפא means “to die” or “to float” or “to increase” or “to close” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 546). טף is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 388). תפי means “to spit” or “to cook” (Jastrow, ibid. 1685). A place called Τεφώ in Palestine is mentioned in 1 Macc 9:50 (H & R Suppl. 150). Alternatively, names beginning with Τεφ are recorded in Egypt (Preisigke, NB, 432; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 315). Perhaps this is an Egyptian name.
I have found no plausible explanation or likely etymology for this name.

This is a Hebrew theophoric name (ηλ=אל). פצי/פצא means “to open” or “to deliver, save” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1204). The name פצאל was used in the Nabatean royal family (e.g. CIS II.I no. 354/3). It is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 468); for Nabateans, (Negev, Qedem 32, no 970); in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 109). For Jews the name is recorded only in Greek. Φασαίαλος is recorded on an Egyptian papyrus (Preisigke, NB, 457). Zunz, Namen, 7, views this as an innovative Hebrew name of the Second Temple period.

Kokknos, Herodian Dynasty, 165, claims that this is a Greek name, but I doubt it. It is perhaps an Idumean name (Oren & Rappaport, IEJ 34 [1984] 146). פרירא/פרידא means “pebble” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1225, 1228). On the interchange of ד and ר see Introduction 2.7.4, and see also under פרידא = Parida B/M. פירורא means “mush, crumble” in Aramaic (Jastrow, ibid. 1171).

The root חזי/חזא means “to discern, see, recognise” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 443). The biblical חזאל (e.g. 2 Kgs 8:8) may derive from the same root. חזא is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 186). Alternatively, χ is often used to transliterate כ in LXX and Josephus, see Introduction 2.1.2.8. כוזא means “pitcher, jug” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 618). The Nabatean כוזא/כוזה is recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 554). Also in Egypt the forms Χοῦς, Χούσης, and Χοῦσος are recorded (Preisigke, NB, 475). Perhaps this is an Egyptian name. It could also be associated with the Edomite god קוס. The name קוסא appears on an Edomite seal (CWSSS, no. 1055). Finally, Justi, INB, 180, records the Persian name “Xusī.”
Ψελλός in Greek means “stammerer.” Although this may also be recorded as a Greek name (WGE, 1697), this is unlikely. The name WGE records are nicknames for two Byzantine authors.
In Greek the name ̓Ωφαλίων is recorded (LGPNI, 489). On Egyptian papyri the name ̓Οφιευς (̓Οφιέως) is recorded often (Preisigke, NB, 250).
